***Version [0.31](/0.31 "0.31")**: This article **may not be** up to date for the [latest stable release](/0.32 "0.32") of Crawl.*

- *This page is about the [status effect](/Status_effect "Status effect"). For the monster spell, see [Paralyse](/Paralyse "Paralyse").*

|   |                                                  |
| - | ------------------------------------------------ |
|   | You are paralysed, and completely unable to act. |

**Paralysis** is a status effect which renders a player or monster unable to move or act for a period of time.

## Contents

- [1 Effect](#Effect)
- [2 Sources](#Sources)
- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)
  - [3.1 Tips & Tricks](#Tips_.26_Tricks)
- [4 Paralysis Spell Table](#Paralysis_Spell_Table)
- [5 History](#History)

## Effect

When paralysed:

- Creatures are unable to act.
- [EV](/EV "EV") is set to almost 0, `2 + size_factor` for players, and set to 0 EV for monsters.
- [SH](/SH "SH") is set to 0.
- Monsters are vulnerable to high-tier [stabs](/Stab "Stab").

Once paralysis ends, players get a brief (1-3 turns) period of immunity to all sources of paralysis. Unlike [sleep](/Sleep "Sleep"), paralysis doesn't end on hit. Unlike [petrification](/Petrification "Petrification"), there is no special damage resistance.

[Formicids](/Formicid "Formicid") are immune to paralysis due to their [stasis](/Stasis "Stasis").

## Sources

There are several sources of paralysis. Some are resistible, while some are not.

Sources of paralysis that can be resisted 100% of the time:

- The spell [Paralyse](/Paralyse "Paralyse"), including [wand of paralysis](/Wand_of_paralysis "Wand of paralysis") (2-5 turns for the player, must overcome the victim's [willpower](/Willpower "Willpower"))
- The melee attacks of a [hornet](/Hornet "Hornet") or [jorogumo](/Jorogumo "Jorogumo") (1-3 turns; [poison resistance](/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance") blocks 2/3 of the time; poison immunity prevents it.)
- The melee attacks of a [formless jellyfish](/Formless_jellyfish "Formless jellyfish") (1 turn; [poison resistance](/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance") blocks 2/3 of the time; poison immunity prevents it.)

Other sources are irresistible for non-Formicids:

- [Stunning Burst](/Stunning_Burst "Stunning Burst") (1 turn; 50% to resist with electricity resistance)
- [Starcursed masses](/Starcursed_mass "Starcursed mass")' shrieking, when 5+ are in sight (1 turn)
- [Zot traps](/Zot_trap "Zot trap") (2-5 turns)
- [Uskayaw](/Uskayaw "Uskayaw")'s or [Zin](/Zin "Zin")'s wrath (2-5 turns)
- Cancelling [Death's Door](/Death%27s_Door "Death's Door") with [Borgnjor's Revivification](/Borgnjor%27s_Revivification "Borgnjor's Revivification") (2-5 turns)
- [Stat zero](/Stat_zero "Stat zero") (2-4 turns, ignores Formicids' stasis)

## Strategy

If a monster's paralysis can last for more than a single turn, it should be treated as ***[instant death](/Instant_death "Instant death")***. Most monsters can kill you if you give them 4-5 free turns. Multiple monsters can *definitely* kill you in 4-5 turns. Even a single turn can cause a huge spike of damage. Having your [EV](/EV "EV") and [SH](/SH "SH") set to 0 is just the cherry on top; paralysis is nasty even for players with high [AC](/AC "AC").

Generally, you should avoid paralysis as much as possible. Even a < 1% chance of instant death is too much for streak play.

### Tips & Tricks

Most sources of paralysis can be dealt with using one way or another:

- The **[Paralyse](/Paralyse "Paralyse") spell** requires line of fire. Spells can't be cast when a monster is [silenced](/Silence "Silence") or [waterlogged](/Waterlog "Waterlog"). [Willpower](/Willpower "Willpower") can protect against it, though it takes high will to reach 0% success. [Racial willpower](/Willpower#Player_resistance "Willpower") matters if you want to reach 0% paralysis. See the table below for more details.

* **[Hornets](/Hornet "Hornet")** are fast enemies which can paralyse on melee. Poison resistance gives a chance to resist the paralysis, but only poison immunity can prevent it. [Wands](/Wand "Wand") can often kill or [polymorph](/Wand_of_polymorph "Wand of polymorph") a hornet with some Evocations training. [Lignification](/Lignification "Lignification") can make it very unlikely for a hornet to kill you by itself, due to [Tree Form](/Tree_Form "Tree Form")'s rPois and increased AC.

- **[Jorogumo](/Jorogumo "Jorogumo")** are also fast enemies with a paralysis melee attack. Their melee works in the same way as hornets', but jorogumo have much better defenses and willpower, in addition to some dangerous ranged spells.

* **[Air elementals](/Air_elemental "Air elemental")** only paralyse for one turn, but when you're in range of a bunch of dangerous opponents, that can be lethal. Evasive, but relatively frail, try to target them with strong never-missing attacks (e.g. [Lee's Rapid Deconstruction](/Lee%27s_Rapid_Deconstruction "Lee's Rapid Deconstruction"), [Airstrike](/Airstrike "Airstrike"), or high Evocations [wand of iceblast](/Wand_of_iceblast "Wand of iceblast"). A [tin of tremorstones](/Tin_of_tremorstones "Tin of tremorstones") can miss, but is very accurate.)

- **[Zot traps](/Zot_trap "Zot trap")** require you or a monster to step on it, and the trap has to be in your [LOS](/LOS "LOS") in order for it to function. Zot traps have a number of other nasty effects, so should be avoided if at all possible.

## Paralysis Spell Table

For the [Paralyse](/Paralyse "Paralyse") spell (and no other source of paralysis), [willpower](/Willpower "Willpower") can resist the effects. Stronger monsters are generally harder to resist. The following amounts of willpower give a 100% chance of resisting - that is, a 0% chance of being paralysed.

| Monster                                                                             | Will | [Human](/Human "Human") (+3 Will/XL) | [Oni](/Oni "Oni") (+4 Will/XL) | [Mummy](/Mummy "Mummy") (+5 Will/XL) | [Felid](/Felid "Felid") (+6 Will/XL) | [Spriggan](/Spriggan "Spriggan") (+7 Will/XL) |
| ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------- | ---- | ------------------------------------ | ------------------------------ | ------------------------------------ | ------------------------------------ | --------------------------------------------- |
| [Orc sorcerer](/Orc_sorcerer "Orc sorcerer")                                        | 135  | XL 19 + Will++ External Will+++      | XL 14 + Will++                 | XL 19 + Will+ XL 11 + Will++         | XL 16 + Will+ External Will++        | XL 20 XL 14 + Will+                           |
| [Ogre mage](/Ogre_mage "Ogre mage")                                                 | 139  | XL 20 + Will++ External Will+++      | XL 15 + Will++                 | XL 20 + Will+ XL 12 + Will++         | XL 17 + Will+ External Will++        | XL 20 XL 15 + Will+                           |
| [Vampire knight](/Vampire_knight "Vampire knight")                                  | 143  | XL 21 + Will++ External Will+++      | XL 16 + Will++                 | XL 21 + Will+ External Will++        | XL 24 XL 18 + Will+                  | XL 21 XL 15 + Will+                           |
| [Fenstrider witch](/Fenstrider_witch "Fenstrider witch") [Sphinx](/Sphinx "Sphinx") | 154  | XL 25 + Will++ External Will+++      | XL 19 + Will++                 | XL 23 + Will+ External Will++        | XL 19 + Will+                        | XL 22 XL 17 + Will+                           |
| [Dread lich](/Dread_lich "Dread lich")                                              | 172  | External Will+++                     | XL 23 + Will++                 | XL 27 + Will+ XL 18 + Will++         | XL 22 + Will+ External Will++        | XL 25 XL 19 + Will+                           |

**Reading the table:**

In-game, willpower is measured by pips of "Will+". But willpower is actually a number from 0-200, with each Will+ adding +40. Every level, you gain a small amount of will dependent on your species. This is relevant when you're trying to reach 0% success - just having Will+++ may not be enough.

A [Human](/Human "Human") requires XL 19 and 2 [rings of willpower](/Rings_of_willpower "Rings of willpower") (or any 2 sources of Will+ beyond level bonus) to reach 0% against an orc sorcerer's paralyse. A Human at XL 19 that displays Will++ in the **%** screen does *not* fully resist a sorcerer. Some cases of low XL are omitted for brevity; Humans technically require XL 5 with external Will+++ to fully resist orc sorcerers.

For absolute safety, make sure to **x v** a monster to make sure that a given spell actually has 0% success.

## History

- Prior to [0.29](/0.29 "0.29"), the Paralyse spell and godly wrath could last from 2-7 turns.
- Prior to [0.27](/0.27 "0.27"), [berserking](/Berserk "Berserk") had a chance to paralyze the player after it ends, and both [Trog](/Trog "Trog") and [berserkitis](/Bad_mutations#Berserk "Bad mutations") would protect from it.
- Prior to [0.25](/0.25 "0.25"), severe [Hexes](/Hexes "Hexes") [miscast effects](/Miscast_effect "Miscast effect") could paralyse the player.
- Prior to [0.24](/0.24 "0.24"), [needles](/Needle "Needle") of paralysis existed.
- Prior to [0.18](/0.18 "0.18"), paralysis could be prevented by an [amulet of stasis](/Amulet_of_stasis "Amulet of stasis").

This page is about the status effect. For the monster spell, see Paralyse.
You are paralysed, and completely unable to act.

Paralysis is a status effect which renders a player or monster unable to move or act for a period of time.

Contents

  • 1 Effect
  • 2 Sources
  • 3 Strategy
    • 3.1 Tips & Tricks
  • 4 Paralysis Spell Table
  • 5 History

Effect

When paralysed:

  • Creatures are unable to act.
  • EV is set to almost 0, 2 + size_factor for players, and set to 0 EV for monsters.
  • SH is set to 0.

Once paralysis ends, players get a brief (1-3 turns) period of immunity to all sources of paralysis. Unlike sleep, paralysis doesn't end on hit. Unlike petrification, there is no special damage resistance.

There are several sources of paralysis. Some are resistible, while some are not.

  • The melee attacks of a formless jellyfish (1 turn; poison resistance blocks 2/3 of the time; poison immunity prevents it.)

  • Stunning Burst (1 turn; 50% to resist with electricity resistance)
  • Starcursed masses' shrieking, when 5+ are in sight (1 turn)
  • Zot traps (2-5 turns)
  • Uskayaw's or Zin's wrath (2-5 turns)

  • Stat zero (2-4 turns, ignores Formicids' stasis)

If a monster's paralysis can last for more than a single turn, it should be treated as instant death. Most monsters can kill you if you give them 4-5 free turns. Generally, you should avoid paralysis as much as possible. Even a < 1% chance of instant death is too much for streak play.

Tips & Tricks

Most sources of paralysis can be dealt with using one way or another:

  • The Paralyse spell requires line of fire. Spells can't be cast when a monster is silenced or waterlogged. Willpower can protect against it, though it takes high will to reach 0% success. Racial willpower matters if you want to reach 0% paralysis. See the table below for more details.
  • Hornets are fast enemies which can paralyse on melee. Poison resistance gives a chance to resist the paralysis, but only poison immunity can prevent it. Wands can often kill or polymorph a hornet with some Evocations training. Lignification can make it very unlikely for a hornet to kill you by itself, due to Tree Form's rPois and increased AC.
  • Jorogumo are also fast enemies with a paralysis melee attack. Their melee works in the same way as hornets', but jorogumo have much better defenses and willpower, in addition to some dangerous ranged spells.
  • Air elementals only paralyse for one turn, but when you're in range of a bunch of dangerous opponents, that can be lethal. Evasive, but relatively frail, try to target them with strong never-missing attacks (e.g. Lee's Rapid Deconstruction, Airstrike, or high Evocations wand of iceblast. A tin of tremorstones can miss, but is very accurate.)
  • Zot traps require you or a monster to step on it, and the trap has to be in your LOS in order for it to function. Zot traps have a number of other nasty effects, so should be avoided if at all possible.

Paralysis Spell Table
